From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

Catalan

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Latin ēlevāre (“to raise”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): (Central) [ə.ləˈβa]
  • IPA(key): (Balearic) [ə.ləˈva]
  • IPA(key): (Valencia) [e.leˈvaɾ]
  • Audio (Barcelona):(file)
  • Rhymes: -a(ɾ)

Verb

[edit]

elevar (first-person singular present elevo, first-person singular preterite eleví, past participle elevat); root stress: (Central, Valencia, Balearic) /e/

  1. to elevate, raise, raise up
  2. (pronomial) to go up, rise

Related terms

[edit]
  • elevació

Further reading

[edit]
  • “elevar”, in Diccionari de la llengua catalana [Dictionary of the Catalan Language] (in Catalan), second edition, Institute of Catalan Studies [Catalan: Institut d'Estudis Catalans], April 2007
  • “elevar”, in Gran Diccionari de la Llengua Catalana, Grup Enciclopèdia Catalana, 2025
  • “elevar” in Diccionari normatiu valencià, Acadèmia Valenciana de la Llengua.
  • “elevar” in Diccionari català-valencià-balear, Antoni Maria Alcover and Francesc de Borja Moll, 1962.

Norwegian Nynorsk

[edit]

Noun

[edit]

elevar m

  1. indefinite plural of elev

Portuguese

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Learned borrowing from Latin ēlevāre (“to raise”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
 
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /e.leˈva(ʁ)/ [e.leˈva(h)]
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /e.leˈva(ʁ)/ [e.leˈva(h)]
    • (São Paulo) IPA(key): /e.leˈva(ɾ)/
    • (Rio de Janeiro) IPA(key): /e.leˈva(ʁ)/ [e.leˈva(χ)]
    • (Southern Brazil) IPA(key): /e.leˈva(ɻ)/
 
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /i.lɨˈvaɾ/
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /i.lɨˈvaɾ/
    • (Northern Portugal) IPA(key): /i.lɨˈbaɾ/ [i.lɨˈβaɾ]
    • (Southern Portugal) IPA(key): /i.lɨˈva.ɾi/

  • Hyphenation: e‧le‧var

Verb

[edit]

elevar (first-person singular present elevo, first-person singular preterite elevei, past participle elevado)

  1. to raise; to lift (to bring or take upwards)
    Synonyms: alçar, alcear, erguer, içar, levantar
    Antonym: baixar
  2. to increase (to make a value or quantity larger)
    Synonym: aumentar
    Antonym: diminuir
  3. (figurative) to put on a pedestal (to hold in very high esteem)
  4. (reflexive) to tower over; to loom over

Related terms

[edit]
  • elevação
  • elevadamente
  • elevadiço
  • elevado
  • elevador
  • elevamento

Spanish

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Latin ēlevāre (“to raise”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /eleˈbaɾ/ [e.leˈβ̞aɾ]
  • Rhymes: -aɾ
  • Syllabification: e‧le‧var

Verb

[edit]

elevar (first-person singular present elevo, first-person singular preterite elevé, past participle elevado)

  1. to elevate
  2. to raise; lift up
    • 2020 October 11, Alejandro Ciriza, El País‎[1]:
      Rafael Nadal eleva, con mascarilla, su 13ª Copa de los Mosqueteros en un ambiente que nada tiene que ver con el de otras ocasiones.
      Rafael Nadal, wearing a mask, lifts up his 13th Musketeers' Trophy in at atmosphere nothing like any other times.
  3. (mathematics) to raise (a number) (to a power)
